 ETHIOPIA SEED SYSTEMS DEVELOPMENT PROJECT I. BACKGROUND A. Project Origin 1. 1 The Transitional Government of Ethiopia (TGE) requested IDA assistance in financing the proposed Seed Systems Development Project. as a part of its efforts to modernize the agriculture sector. and alleviate growing food security concerns. The Project was appraised in February/March 1992 and re-appraised in July/August 1994. B. The Macro Setting 1.2 Ethiopia, with a population of 54.8 million, is Sub-Saharan Africa's second most populous country. Its social indicators are among the lowest in the world: very low per capita GNP of US$125 per year, high infant mortality rate of 122 per 1,000 live births, mortality rate of over 20 percent for children under five, and growing chronic protein energy malnutrition. According to TGE's Rural Nutrition survey (1992), 64 percent of the children are stunted and 47 percent are underweight. Only 17 percent of the children complete four years of primary school against the regional and global averages of 48 and 68 percent. respectively. 1.3 Some 60 percent of the urban population lives below the poverty level. The estimated average per capita calorie intake is below 80 percent of the level considered necessary for a healthy life. The country's structural food deficit, presently estimated to be around one million tons. is anticipated to grow steadily, unless specific actions are taken, aimed at improving productivity in the primarv agricultural sector. In the last two decades, annual population growth averaged about 3 percent, and is projected in the 1993 World Development Report at 2.7 percent until the turn of the century. 1.4 The country suffers from severe port and transport capacity constraints. With Eritrea's independence in May 1993, Ethiopia lost its two ports, Assab and Massawa, and became landlocked. Although an agreement between the two countries (July 1993) provides Ethiopia an unhindered access to Assab and Massawa, the severe capacity constraints are not likely to permit a significant increase in dry cargo (food and fertilizer) imports. In addition. there are serious transportation constraints aggravated by the inadequacy and poor state of its roads. Ethiopia's road density is among the lowest in Africa, standing at 20 km per 1,000 km sq. and 0.4 km per 1,000 population. Some 80 percent of Ethiopians depend on traditional means of transport, such as walking, carrying their goods on the back and head, on pack animals and, to a lesser extent, on animal drawn carts. Household food security, in dispersed, difficult to reach and mountainous locations, where much of the population resides, is a matter of growing concern. 1.5 The Ethiopian political and economic structures have been subject to repeated and profound changes during the past two decades. The 1974 revolution ended an era of monarchy and feudalism; it replaced market mechanisms with state planning and controls over investment, production and trade, stifled private entrepreneurship, and diverted resources to the conduct of civil war, which virtually crippled the economy. The socialist military regime was defeated in May 1991, and a National Conference, comprising a coalition of 29 parties, ethnic and linguistic groups, installed a Transitional Government (TGE) in June 1991. TGE is in the process of introducing new economic and administrative structures and a democratic political system. 1.6 Market-oriented Economic System: In November 1991, TGE announced Ethiopia's Economic Policy during the Transitional Period, which signaled a move away from the centrally planned economy towards a more liberal, market oriented and decentralized economic system, in which private, rather than collective, ownership would dominate most sectors of the economy and efficiency would be stimulated by competition and increased international openness. In the meantime, to jump-start the economy, an Emergency Recovery and Reconstruction Project (ERRP), Cr. 2351-ET, was launched in July 1992 in cooperation with other donors, involving a total
 -2- provision of about US$650 million to be disbursed in two and half years. ERRP, due to close in September 1995. has been satisfactorily implemented. 1.7 TGE's first phase of economic reform aimed at increasing domestic resource mobilization, reducing the fiscal deficit, correcting price distortions, and reducing the external account deficit. The most significant reform was a 59 percent devaluation of the Birr (in US dollars terms) in October 1992 and the introduction of a limited bi- weekly foreign exchange auction system in May 1993--a move towards a market-determined rate of exchange. Other important reforms are aimed at improving incentives for production, competitiveness of markets, and private sector performance. These efforts have been supported by a Structural Adjustment Credit (Cr. 2526-ET) funded by IDA and other donors. TGE has also reached agreements with the Bank and IMF on the next phase of reform presented in the Third Policy Framework Paper negotiated in September 1994 for the period 1994-95 to 1996-97. A public expenditure review (1994) by IDA confirms TGE commitment to a policy which shifts the weight of investment, and management of the productive sectors, from the state to the private sectors. The economy has responded positively to these reforms. Real GDP grew by 12.3 percent in FY93, compared to a -3.2 percent in FY92. Exports increased sharply, balance of payments improved, and foreign exchange reserves have increased, whereas the gap between the official foreign exchange auction rate and parallel rate has narrowed to less than 15 percent. Domestic inflation decreased to less than 10 percent from an average of 15.7 percent in the preceding three years, and is now projected at about 5 percent per year after FY95. 1.8 Decentralized Administrative System: In order to provide a sound basis for grass roots economic growth with the people's participation. TGE had divided the country into 14 regions; however, the newly adopted constitution by the Constituent Assembly divides the country into nine states. namely Tigray, Afar, Amhara, Oromia, Somali, Benishangul, Southern Nation, Gambella and Harrar. These state governments will have legislative, executive and judicial powers in respect to all matters within their geographical areas except certain subjects where the Central Government alone would have power. In order to implement the new arrangements, a massive shift of staff from the Central Government to various regions is under way. 1.9 Such simultaneous handling of profound systemic changes in the economic, political, administrative and institutional structures of Ethiopia is an effort of unprecedented magnitude. Inevitably, it will take time to fully establish effective organizational structures and functional relationships to sustain a high level of economic performance in a democratic political environment. C. The Agricultural Sector 1.10 Sectoral Contribution: The agriculture sector is the leading sector in the Ethiopian economy; it accounts for 55 percent of GDP at factor costs, employs 80 percent of the labor force, generates 60 percent of commodity export earnings., in which coffee alone accounts for 60 percent, and provides raw materials for 70 percent of the country;s large and medium-sized industries that are agro-based. Crop production is estimated to contribute around 60 percent, livestock around 30 percent, and forestry and other sectors around 10 percent of the total sectoral output. Over six million (estimated) smallholders, cultivating about six to seven million hectares of land, follow a traditional, low input-low output rainfed farming technology and account for about 96 percent of agricultural output., including 98 percent of the coffee. The balance is produced on state farms and by other public agricultural enterprises. Depending on the crop situation, only about 20 to 30 percent of the cereal production comes to the local market. 1.11 Sectoral Performance: The performance of the agriculture sector in the last two decades has been poor. While the economy grew at 2.2 percent during the last 18 years, the annual agricultural growth averaged around only 1I.1 percent. The area under crops, as well as the overall production, has remained stagnant for several years, barring certain exceptional years like 1983 and 1989. Crop productivity has also remained low at average per hectare yields of 1.2 tons for food grains, 0.6 tons for pulses and 0.5 tons for oilseeds, compared to relatively much higher yields (more than double in many cases) obtained at research stations and in demonstrations conducted at
 -3- farm level. As a result, barring the exceptional year of 1983, the country has been a net importer of foodgrains since 1981. The level of foodgrain imports required to meet the country's deficit rose from three percent of the total grain consumption in the early 1980s to about 10 percent in 1990. In addition, according to Central Statistical Authority (CSA) 1989 Agricultural Sample Survey, 46.7 percent of 6.09 million households (excluding Eritrea, Tigray, Assab and Ogaden region) have holdings which average less than 0.5 ha each; cumulatively 72.1 percent have holdings less than one hectare (average size of holding being 0.73 ha) Further, assuming a family size of five and normal cereal productivity, a tqpical farm household may need about 0.75 ha of land to obtain a food supply of about 0.9 tons per annum to stay above the absolute poverty line. Based on this criteria, over 60 percent of the rural households may be in absolute poverty. 1.12 Other Causes of Poor Sectoral Performance: These include: (a) inadequate research and extension support; (b) virtual stagnation of crop production technology at primitive levels, except very limited introduction of modern inputs like fertilizer, and to a very limited extent, seeds of improved varieties; (c) recurrent droughts, limited area under irrigation (less than three percent of the total area) despite significant potential; and (d) declining soil fertility due to overgrazing, reduced fallow, and very rapid deforestation (from 16 percent in the early 1950s to only 2.7 percent in 1989). Even though some useful work has been done by the Ethiopian agricultural research system in the development and release of improved crop varieties, farmers' access to seeds of genetically superior varieties remains very poor. In fact, a recent meeting of international agricultural research centers with the World Bank (October 1994) came to the conclusion that the most critical constraint to widespread adoption of improved technologies, particularly the disease-resistant, high yielding varieties, was the poor capacity within the country for producing and multiplying the improved seeds or planting materials. 1.13 Source of Growth: TGE's recent agricultural strategy identifies two main sources of growth in agricultural output: (a) increase in smallholder crop productivitv, and (b) area expansion through (i) extensive mechanized farming; and (ii) intensive commercial agriculture. 1.14 Area Expansion: The scope of increasing area under crops in the central highlands, where much of agriculture is currently practiced, is severely limited due to growing population pressure combined with the largest livestock herd in Africa. Land scarcity has led to the increase of cropped area at the expense of both fallow and grazing, with crops being grown on more marginal, steep and poorly drained lands which are susceptible to erosion. It would, therefore, be necessary for cropped area expanslon to move to lower elevations, mostly in the west and south of the country where population density is much lower. However, this would entail considerable amount of lead time and investment, as these areas are generally: (a) uninhabited or have sparse population; (b) malaria infested and tsetse fly infested; (c) lacking in minimum infrastructure like roads, clinics, banks, electricity, potable water, schools, telecommunications; and (d) deprived of access to cheap labor due to absence of housing and other facilities. Further, the environmental impact of sudden opening of large areas of land combined with new human settlements would need careful study. The sociological aspects of settling people in other regions would also need to be addressed. Area expansion would, therefore, be only a medium to long-term option and would not significantly address the problem of rising food shortages in the next few years. 1.15 Yield Enhancement: The only available short term alternative to meet the critical need for increased foodgrains production is by increasing land productivity. There are several mutually reinforcing ways of achieving enhanced productivity levels in agriculture. These include widespread use of improved seeds, better cultural practices, site-specific solutions to low productivity through intensive research and extension work, minimization of post harvest losses, greater and more efficient use of chemical and organic fertilizers, and more efficient pest management techniques. However, given the current situation in Ethiopia, under which: (a) the entire public administration system is being revamped; (b) the agricultural research and extension system is being reviewed for thorough reform; (c) work on site-specific crop productivity problems is yet to commence; (d) the domestic manufacture and commercial sale of improved agricultural implements and thrashers has not commenced; (e) the important institution of rural cooperatives needs to be virtually re-created under the new cooperative law; (f) the Agricultural and Industrial Development Bank (AIDB) and the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE), the two primary institutions for rural credit, are being restructured and re-capitalized; and (g) the state farms, mainly responsible for limited seed production, are being downsized and commercialized, it would be difficult to expect
 -4- synergistic contributions from several of these options at least for the next few years. Nevertheless, it is possible to begin with some specific initiatives which would progressively draw support from the above-mentioned institutional and other improvements. 1.16 Figure I in the section on Annexes depicts a 20-year scenario of food production and consumption needs from 1974 to 1994. The country's food deficit which started in 1981 is now around one million tons of foodgrains per year. What is of greater concern is the projection that by 1999, Ethiopian's gross foodgrains requirement will increase by 2.35 million tons over the 1994 estimated levels. In this context, it would be prudent for the Government to launch some basic initiatives to provide agriculture support services to farmers, which would include adequate and satisfactory input supplies of seeds and fertilizer, combined with a strengthened extension service. The Government is already working in this direction. A task force set up in August 1994, is exploring ways of (a) upgrading the skills of extension agents through well-focused training programs; and (b) ensuring timely and adequate supplies of agricultural inputs-particularly improved seeds and fertilizers-to the farmers. D. IDA's Agricultural Portfolio and Future Strategy 1.17 IDA's Existing Portfolio: IDA's existing agricultural portfolio is rather thin, and comprises two Projects only. One project in agricultural research and one project in forestry have closed in June 1994, while one in livestock closed in December of 1994. There has been no new IDA lending for the agriculture sector since 1989. IDA efforts have mainly concentrated on policy dialogue, sector work (in areas of food security, poverty alleviation and forestry sector) and the strengthening of the future pipeline. Since TGE came into office in mid-1991, the Bank has reviewed ongoing operations with a view to restructuring projects established under the previous regime, and freeing up resources for deployment in support of speedy economic recovery operations, and in realigning the project designs with the Governments' new economic management and development vision. IDA has also proposed further sector work to TGE.  -5- H. THE SEED SECTOR A. Introduction 2.1 Role of Seed in Agriculture: Seed is a basic input in crop production. It is also the cheapest input in agriculture, yet it has the most profound influence on crop yields. The productivity of a crop is directly linked to the genetic potential of the seed used, and varies according to the use of recommended complementary inputs and the observance of cultural practices. Further, since seed production is a biological phenomenon, it is characterized by an inflexible time lag which is required to multiply a small quantity of breeder seed into large quantities for commercial sale through a multi-stage production process over successive crop seasons. These stages are usually described as pre-basic, basic and commercial seed production. Also, since seed is a living organism, subject to the phenomena of aging, decay and death, it needs sensitive care in handling, storage and transportation. Finally, unlike chemical fertilizers which are mass produced in large factories with built-in quality control arrangements, seed lots, which are usually produced by numerous seed producers in different farming conditions, need to be carefully tested for quality before they are sold in the market. The quality considerations include attention to genetic and physical purity of a variety, presence of weed-seeds, generation (i.e.. stage of multiplication, such as pre-basic, basic and commercial, also known as breeder, foundation and commercial respectively), germination percentage, moisture content and the date of testing. B. Historical Development 2.2 The Informal Seed Sector: For centuries, the Ethiopian farmers have used their own seed saved from the previous crop, or informally obtained it from neighboring farmers, usually in exchange for grain or any other commodity. These seeds, also described as "land races", have been going through a natural mutation process over time to produce new genetic versions of seed varieties to fit each agro-ecological niche. Even today, some 85 percent of the Ethiopian farmers are believed to be depending upon these seeds. Though well adapted to the local agro-ecological situations, and therefore resistant to factors like disease, insect attack or even moisture stress, "land races" are generally low yielding when compared to modern high yielding varieties bred in agricultural research stations which have a relatively wider adaptability in a range of environments and have a built-in responsiveness to the application of chemical inputs like fertilizers. 2.3 The Formal Seed Sector: The formal seed sector in Ethiopia owes its origin to the establishment of the Alemaya University of Agriculture (AUA) in the mid-fifties and the Institute of Agricultural Research (IAR) in the mid-sixties, when these institutions started developing improved varieties of seeds for the cereal, pulses and oilseed crops. These seeds were first introduced to the farmers in 1967 under the Swedish-assisted first minimum package program in the Chilalo .Awraja in the Arsi zone. The Chilalo Agricultural Development Unit, popularly known as CADU, supplied a package of inputs and services which included improved seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, credit and extension advice to the farmers. CADU's success induced similar minimum package programs in other regions; funding was provided by several international agencies including IDA, USAID, FAO, while the projects were implemented by the Ministry of Agriculture's Extension and Project Implementation Department. By the mid- 1980s, it is estimated that about 21 percent of Arsi Region farmers had adopted improved variety seeds, compared to only about 2 percent in other regions. 2.4 Ethiopian Seed Corporation: Production of improved commercial seed for cereal, legume and oilseed crops was institutionalized in 1978 through the parastatal Ethiopian Seed Corporation (ESC); this corporation was recently converted into the Ethiopian Seed Enterprise (ESE). The ESC was under the supervisory authority of the Ministry of State Farms, Coffee and Tea Development, while ESE is now responsible to the Prime Minister's Office. The main objectives of ESC were to (a) organize the production and marketing of improved seeds developed by the IAR and other agricultural research establishments; (b) import reliable high yielding varieties; and (c) organize seed cleaning and processing facilities at various locations. Until 1990, ESE was virtually the
 -6- sole producer of seeds in the formal seed sector. It obtained the breeder seed from the IAR and AUA and multiplied it into pre-basic and basic seed at its two seed farms or the farms of the IAR/AUA, and finally into commercial seed almost exclusively at the state farms. ESE infrastructure includes a stationary seed processing capacity of about 40,000 tons per season (with two working shifts) at four locations (Nekempt. Assela, Kofele, Awassa) and 10,000 tons from three mobile cleaners, permanent storage capacity of 37,700 tons at eight locations, (Nekempt, Assela, Kofele, Awassa, Bahir Dar, Assassa, Dodolla and Robe) with an additional seed reserve store (2,000 tons) at Kombolcha. ESE also has a seed testing laboratory at Addis Ababa with a capacity to test 5,000 samples per year. During the last five years, its annual production has averaged about 12,450 tons of cleaned seed, or 12 percent of the total potential market, estimated to be around 100,000 tons. Historically. four crops, namely, wheat, maize, teff and barley out of 14 traded crops, comprised 80 to 90 percent of sales. Typically the state farms would absorb some 43 percent of the seed produced, the remainder being distributed to the peasants through Non- Governmental Organizations (NGOs) (30 percent) and Agricultural Inputs Supply Corporation (AISCO) (27 percent). In 1991, AISCO ceased to deal with seeds and ESE expanded its supplies for drought relief operations. ESE's production planning, distribution and seed pricing was clearly subject to government regulations and policy. Despite recent policy relaxation, private retailing of improved seeds has not vet commenced and seed quality remains a critical issue. ESE sells uncertified seed. 2.5 In July 1990, a Joint Venture Agreement was signed between the Ethiopian Seed Corporation and Pioneer Hi-bred International, USA to procure. produce, process. condition, distribute and sell seeds and other agricultural products domestically, as well as in the export markets. The respective shares of the two companies are 30 and 70 percent. This joint venture has so far focused on production of hybrid seeds for maize. Lately, the joint venture has also started the testing of sunflower and alfalfa seeds and is expected to continue with a program of adaptive research in varieties with commercial potential. C. Policy Framework 2.6 Policy Environment: For the first time, in October 1992, the TGE announced a National Seed Industry Policy (NSIP) to help the country develop a healthy seed industry in line with the national economic development policy, in which the domestic private seed enterprises would be encouraged to actively participate in the production and distribution of improved seeds. Hitherto, the private sector had virtually no role in the production and marketing of seeds. The principal objectives of NSIP include: (a) ensure the collection, conservation, documentation and utilization of the germplasm resource for future use by national research programs; (b) streamline variety evaluation, release, registration and maintenance activities through a new organizational set-up; (c) develop an effective system of producing and supplying high quality seeds of important crops to satisfy the national seed requirements through active participation of both public and private sector; (d) encourage the participation of farmers in germplasm conservation as well as seed production; (e) create a functional and efficient organizational set-up to facilitate cooperative linkage and coordination between the various participants in the seed industry; and (f) regulate seed quality standards, import and export, seed trade quarantine, and other seed related issues. Further, the policy provides for the setting up of a National Seed Industry Agency (NSIA), under the umbrella of a National Seed Industry Council (NSIC), to guide and monitor the growth of the national seed industry along sound lines. The NSIP also seeks to define the role of the public and the private sectors in seed industry development, promote active farmer participation, strengthen the system of seed quality control, lay down arrangements for variety testing and release, and promote secondary seed multiplication schemes at community/village levels, using both local and improved cultivars. Finally, unlike in the past, the NSIP requires that the price of seed be determined by market forces. The policy is clearly cognizant of the natural resource conservation and sustainability concerns. As a follow-up to the policy, the TGE issued a proclamation (No. 56/1993 of July 16, 1993) establishing the NSIA and NSIC to implement NSIP, and to assure the overall growth of a broad-based seed industrv. The policy is expected to be followed by a seed legislation to regulate the industry on a sound basis, and protect the interests of the plant breeders, distributors and farmers.
 -7- D. Current Status of the Seed Sector 2.7 Breeders Seed: IAR and AUA are the main plant breeding institutions in Ethiopia; there is as yet no private plant breeding activity. The IAR, operating from 14 main research centers and 29 sub-centers, is the principal plant breeding institution for cereal crops, pulses, oilseeds, cotton, potato and forage crops. The AUA. with two centers and seven sub-centers is specializing in the improvement of teff, durum wheat, pulses, potato and forages, through its teaching staff on a part time basis, except at the Debre Zeit station. Breeders in both institutions have concentrated on crop varieties which have the greatest potential across as wide a spectrum of agro-ecological zones (AEZs) as possible. However, even though research is well organized at these institutes, their resources are inadequate compared to the needs of Ethiopia, which has a vast variability of agro-ecological conditions. Despite these constraints., some 60 improved varieties, have been released in the last 10 years. Of these, 30 varieties of cereals, five varieties of food legumes and six varieties of oilseeds are currently used by ESE. A serious lacuna, however, is the absence of research in seed technology for developing seed standards for seed quality and seed health care. 2.8 The breeders seed production program suffers from a lack of manpower. and from equipment and infrastructural constraints. As a result, it has been difficult to maintain the variety's original characteristics and uniformity. Serious difficulties have also been experienced in roguing some foundation seed fields as distinguishing morphological characters for the released varieties included in the program were not readily available from the breeders. Further, once a variety is approved for release, IAR and AUA are often unable to produce breeder seed in quantities sufficient for multiplication; for example, only 380 kg of breeder seed was produced in 1992 against the total demand of 1. 1 tons. Thus, there hlave been serious gaps in the systematic flow of adequate quantities of breeder seed from the research institutions to the producers of basic seeds, because of lack of proper seed processing and threshing equipment, and storage facilities. 2.9 Despite the problems with the currently available quality and quantity of breeder seeds, however, the basic research program is making good progress. The program has a number of promising technologies in its pipeline with varieties released or under active development for several priority food crops. In basic research efforts, Ethiopia has enjoyed the active collaboration of many of the international research centers (CIMMYT, IITA, ICRISAT, ICARDA, ILCA, and CIAT) in addition to the IDA-supported Agricultural Research Project (Credit 1521-ET). 2.10 The joint venture company, Ethiopia Pioneer Hi-bred Seeds Inc., is currently engaged in an active testing program for their imported hybrid maize. Results are promising; already one variety (medium maturity cycle) of hybrid maize (PHB 3435) has been submitted for release by the National Variety Release Committee (NVRC). Another maize variety (PHB 3253) is expected to be evaluated for release very shortly. The joint venture started testing of sunflower and alfalfa seeds and will carrv out a continuous program of adaptive seed research in Ethiopia where commercial potential warrants. 2.11 Variety Release Mechanism: Like many other countries, testing of newly developed varieties, and release and registration of these is carried out by NVRC. NVRC was established in 1982 and is composed of breeders, agronomists, crop protection experts and social scientists from the various institutions including research centers. Since its establishment, NVRC has released more than 29 varieties of cereals, 17 varieties of oilseed crops. 7 pulse varieties. 7 cotton varieties, and 7 vegetable tuber varieties. Lessons Learned 2.29 With regard to the informal seed sector, there are some useful lessons from Secondary Seed Multiplication Schemes (SSMS) which have been tried in a number of countries-I-. A major conclusion is that farmer-managed seed systems are not a substitute for the conventional seed system based on seed enterprises; both systems are complementary, and entrepreneurs from the informal system would gradually evolve into formal enterprises. In the most successful informal systems, the emphasis has been on farmers' training and extension advice In Malawi. the Secondary Seed Multiplication Scheme Component did not succeed because farmers could not freely sell the seed, but were instead compelled to deliver seed to the Government, whereby seed prices were state controlled and subsidized. In Senegal and Gambia, communally managed seed plots were not nearly as well maintained as seed plots managed by individual farmers. However, the scheme provided training, helped conduct demonstrations in farmers' fields and tried to teach the farmers "how to do better what they have been doing for centuries." In Senegal. the informal seed multiplication system worked well, but being heavily donor/NGO dependent, sustainability is the issue. In Nepal. the system has been in place for over 10 years; a lesson from this experience is that the more a system is decentralized, the more efficiently it works. For instance, working with farm families was better than working with groups; storage bins for individual farmers proved more effective than mini-seed houses to clean and store up to 40 tons of seeds. Further, small farmers often opted for seed exchange, rather than buying seed against cash; subsidies in the formal seed sector discouraged farmers from producing their own seed. Another important lesson is that it takes about five years to build sufficient momentum to make the program sustainable, provided appropriate backstopping and support from extension continues. A USAID study in three villages of Cameroon's Central Province, where farm trials were simultaneously conducted, shows that 90 percent of the farmers were using improved maize varieties. These lessons have been taken into account when designing the SSMS component of the Project. 2.30 In the case of the formal seed sector, a number of lessons have been learned from past experience. Twelve years (1979-91) of Ethiopian experience with full state controls is an example of how a seed system should not be run. The system led to (a) under-utilization of seed processing and storage capacities; (b) scant attention to the scientific rigors necessary in the system, i.e., missing out on basic seed production, and near total disregard of the most critical ingredient in a successful seed system, namely, quality control; (c) absence of supporting institutional and legal structures (like the recently set up NSIA, and a seed law) to promote the interest of the subsector; (d) neglect of the most important clients (viz., the peasants) who produce 90 percent of the country's crops; (e) a non- commercial approach combined with stringent seed and foodgrain price controls; and, as a result, (f) continuing losses for ESE, and severely limited benefits to the economy. However, the improvements/reforms, initiated by TGE since 1991, are already beginning to show results. ESE has turned the page and has made a profit ever since prices of seed and food grains were liberalized. The basic thrust of IDA's experience in other countries (in Sub- Saharan Africa alone IDA has some 39 completed or ongoing Projects with a seed component, and three self- standing seed projects) points in a similar direction. An internal review by the Bank of the past experience and future needs in the seed sector shows a disproportionate placement of seed investments in the public sector; relative neglect of the private sector, absence of a conducive policy environment which would encourage private sector involvement in the technological functions of the seed sector (including plant breeding, product development, import of technology and subsequent dissemination), reliance upon a single institution and ad hoc interventions by the Government, have generally met with poor success. On the other hand, areas of relative success have included investments in institutional development, technical assistance and training. These lessons have been built into the design of the project by directing a major part of the credit for the development of the formal sector as well as the informal sector. 1' These experiences have been documented in Bal and Douglas' "Designing Successful Farmer-Managed Seed Systems (Winroch 1992)" and AFTD's "Seed Systems in Sub-Saharan Africa-Issues and Options".

Firt. the proposed seed system should be specific to Ethiopia; it must be consistent with the evolutionary stage of its economic policies and fit with the level of agricultural and infrastructural development, as well as with the maturity of its institutions. In seed program development, the seed requirements of all parties playing a role in agricultural production have to be met. As far as the crops are concerned, a broad-based distinction can be made between strategic staple crops like maize, sorghum, teff, wheat, barley, pulses and oilseeds, and high value crops like vegetables, fruits, flowers, potatoes and hybrid agricultural crops. The former are grown mainly by the poor peasant population, the latter by the more developed farming communities. Seed supply of (non-hybrid) staple crops is characterized by low profit margins, whereas seed supply of high value crops and hybrid staple crops is characterized by relatively high profit margins. To cater to the seed requirements of the population, the project proposes to develop a diversified approach: (a) Ethiopian Seed Enterprise (ESE)-to produce high quality certified or truthfully labeled seed of staple crops for seed end-users, including input-responsive farmers, larger scale commercial farms and the peasant sector. (b) Secondary Seed Multiplication Schemes (SSMS)-to produce non-certified seed at the village level, in various organizational models. This seed will be considerably cheaper than ESE seed, thus catering to the poor peasant farmer end-user, mostly on a barter basis. (c) Seedsmen/Seed Farmer Groups-to produce, process and market commercial (truthfully labeled) seed of staple crops on a medium scale in competition with ESE. (d) Other Seed Enterprises-to produce, process and market certified/truthfully labeled seeds of different crops. functioning as wholesalers, retailers for ESE certified or truthfully labeled seed, joint venture seed enterprises, fruit tree/seedling nurseries, etc. Seedsmen/Seed Farmer Groups 2. Experience has shown that in countries that have liberalized their seed programs the production, processing and marketing of high yielding varieties of staple crops is taken up by the private sector. Seedsmen, usually leading progressive farmers or local businessmen dealing in agricultural inputs, and/or small groups of seed farmers may decide to produce seed on a commercial, medium scale. These developments will be actively stimulated by the National Seed Industry Agency (NSIA) under the Seed Systems Development Project (SSDP). 3. The prerequisites for the evolution of seedsmen and seed farmer groups are (a) access to credit facilities; (b) access to the required technological know-how; (c) access to basic/certified seed of improved and high yielding varieties; and (d) a market-based pricing system for seed. As seedsmen and seed farmer groups are likely to produce crops and varieties similar to those of ESE, they will

For the developments described above to take place, therefore, it is essential that ESE prices its seed at non-subsidized market prices, as pricing of public seed below cost recovery levels will preclude the entry into the seed business by the private sector. The proposed Seed Systems Development Project (SSDP) has been rated Category B for environmental assessment, as the environmental issues to be addressed are limuted and narrow in scope. The main issue relates to pest management and the use of pesticides in seed production and processing. In addition, it is desirable to examine the potential impact of the project on the genetic diversity of crop species in Ethiopia. Pest Management and Pesticides 2 Pesticide use in the seed sector includes seed dressing (applied either at a conditioning plant or at the user level) to control seed-borne or soil-borne pests and diseases, treatment of fumigation of stored seeds to control post- harvest pests and diseases, and field application of pesticides to protect growing plants (breeder seed production and bulking up). The proposed project would provide support for seed production, processing and storage, both directlv for ESE operations and through assistance for the development of private sector initiatives through NSIA. It is beyond the scope of this project to attempt to establish a broad-based integrated pest management (1PM) program for production of food crops in Ethiopia. However, IDA policies require that the project promote rational pest management methods within the activities supported by the project, and that it include specific measures to minimize human and environmental hazards by supporting appropriate selection. use and handling of pesticides. 3. A national pesticide legislation enacted recently uill soon introduce a pesticide registration scheme which will set standards for pesticide importation, production and use in Ethiopia, based on effectiveness, health and environmental impacts. Until this scheme is put into effect, however, steps must be taken to ensure appropnate pesticide selection and use consistent with the Government's policies and objectives as well as IDA policies and guidelines. 4. Technical issues and institutional responsibilities relating to pesticides and pest management differ between the existing state farm and peasant sectors. It can be anticipated that some simnilar distinctions will continue to be appropriate in the future between the peasant sector and any large-scale, commercially-oriented operations which may supplement or replace the state farms. For purposes of the proposed project, this generally parallels the distinction between components to strengthen the public sector and "forrnal" private sector capacity for production, processing and marketing of seeds, versus the informal (peasant) sector "secondary seed multiplication scheme,'(SSMS). The relevant issues for each sector are discussed below. Fertilizer Users 5. The State Farm and the Formal Commercial Sector: The ESE currently provides seeds directly to state farms, pre-treating them with insecticides and fungicides at its seed conditioning plants. The MSFCTD's Agricultural Research and Advisory Department (ARAD) is responsible for recommending which products are used, based on its own criteria (e.g. product must be registered in at least two countries) and field testing for effectiveness. Currently recommended are various commercial mnixtures of non-systemic fungicides (e.g. Thiram) and insecticides (e.g. Lindan, Furadan). These products are acceptable under IDA guidelines and their procurement can therefore be supported under the project. However, the products shown in the negative list of pesticides (see below) would not be considered for financing under the project. 6. The ESE is also conscious of %%orker health and safety in handling seed treatment chemical in its seed processing plants, using an automated method involving slurries in order to reduce exposure and dust contamination. Handling will be further improved under the project as rehabilitation of the seed processing plants will include better isolation/compartmentalization of the seed treatment equipment.
 - 82 - Annex 13 Page 2 of 3 7. For stored product pest control. MSFCTD/ARAD recommends Aluminum Phosphide as a fumigant and pyrimiphos methyl (Actellic) and Malathion to spray surfaces of storage facilities. These products are acceptable under [DA guidelines. 8. MSFCTD indicated that pesticide use in the field for food crops is largely limited to herbicides, as xkecds are the major production constraint. Pesticide treatment is only very rarely required for control of animal pests or diseases of these crops. A list of the herbicides, fungicides and insecticides currently recommended by MSFCTD/ARAD for maize, sorghum, wvheat. barlev, teff. pulses, various beans. sesame, rape seed. sunflower. fruits and vegetables; is available in the project files. The list also indicates those products not to be procured with assistance from IDA. 9. Because the project will promote the entry of new participants in the seed processing and marketing business. it will be necessary to ensure proper selection and handling of seed treatment chemicals beyond direct ESE and state farms operations. The NSIC should include this aspect in the proposed Seed Act. At the same time, NSIA will be responsible for including seed treatment aspect in its advice and assistance to individuals and cnterprises entering the business, ensuring that these processes are in accordance with government regulations and with IDA guidelines. 10. The Peasant Sector: The Agricultural Inputs Supply Enterprise (AISCO) is responsible for distributing fertilizers and pesticides to peasant farmers. The majority of pesticides provided through AISCO are currently procured under an IDA-financed project, and therefore subject to IDA approval. However, some pesticides not eligible for IDA financing are purchased using resources from other donors. 11. ESE does not pre-treat seeds it supplies for the peasant sector, due to the risk that excess treated seeds may be sold or used for food or animal feed. ESE and MOA recommendation, which IDA endorses, is that treated seed should not be provided to the peasant sector as a whole until the agricultural extension system is strong enough to provide the necessary education and technical support. 12. AISCO does, however, provide seed dressing chemicals to some peasant farmers so that they can treat their own seed or, in some cases, have their seed treated for them by local agricultural extension agents at the distribution centers. In general, seed treatment is an acceptable crop protection method, preferable to the alternative of greater use of pesticide spraying. However, it is recognized that the agricultural extension service is not yet sufficiently strong to provide sufficient training and technical support to peasant farmers to ensure that seed dressings are handled safely and effectively. The MOA is beginning to address this by developing appropriate training and extension materials with the assistance of an FAO consultant. Nevertheless, great caution must continue to be exercised regarding the level of toxicity of seed treatment chemicals (as with any pesticides) to be handled and used by poorly educated small-scale farmers. 13. It is therefore of great concern that the seed dressings currently provided to peasant farmers in some areas where termites are deemed to be a problem contain materials such as Aldrin and Chlordane/Heptachlor, which are highly toxic and therefore banned or severely restricted in a large number of countries. 14. As the new committee responsible for establishing pesticide regulations and registration carries out its task of deternining which products will be permitted for use in Ethiopia in the future, it is to be hoped that use of these products will discontinued entirely. Together with the IAR it should also examine the cost-effectiveness of using insecticidal seed treatments against termites and other soil-borne pests. In the meantime, it must be noted that these products are not eligible for financing by IDA and should not be recommended or used in any activity supported or promoted under the project. 15. Under the Secondary Seed Multiplication Scheme, MOA staff will be responsible to identify appropriate pest management methods, both chemical and non-chemical (including seed processing, seed production and seed storage), and to assist and train the participants to use them.
 - 83 - Annex 13 Page 3 of 3 Maintaining Genetic Diversity 16. Ethiopia is the center of origin for a number of food crops of regional and world-wide importance. Farmers all over the countrv continue to grow and select primitive cultivars of indigenous crop species ("landraces") as well as those of some important introduced crop species. The genetic diversity of some crops such as wsheat, sorghum, millet and teff grown by farmers throughout Ethiopia may be as great or greater than is found anvwhere else in the world. The biological diversity embodied in these landraces and primitive cultivars represents a priceless genetic store of characteristics such as drought tolerance, insect and disease resistance, specific agronomic and nutritional traits. etc. * hich are equally (and in some cases more) important as straight -ield, particularly for subsistence-level farmers. While the introduction and development of higher-yielding varieties is clearly necessarv to achieve agricultural growth, there is a risk that these modem varieties will displace and eliminate the indigenous genetic resource base unless specific measures are taken to ensure that it is incorporated effectively into breeding programs and is maintained and continues to evolve as a source of genetic raw material for the future. 17. This objective is being addressed in part by an On-farm Conservation" project which is supported by a consortium of Canadian NGOs, headed by the Unitarian Service Committee of Canada (now USC/C). T'he On- farm Conservation program, implemented in collaboration with the Ethiopian Plant Genetic Resources Centre (PGRCIE), encourages peasant farmers in selected (particularly drought-affected) areas to continue growing local landraces of several staple crops which are in danger of being displaced by more modem varieties. The breeder seed is obtained from PGRC/E, from IAR breeders and from farmers themselves. The project assists and supervises production of seeds of selected landraces and primitive varieties, buys excess seed from the farmers at an attractive price, and distributes it to other farmers to grow in the next season. 18. The On-farm Conservation project in Ethiopia is one component of a broader "Seeds of Survival" (SOS) program which aims to promote development of a sustainable, long-term, secure and abundant food supply in Africa through the preservation, enhancement and distribution of the genetic diversity of food crops. Other elements of the SOS include training (international in scope, held twice yearly in Ethiopia), technical assistance, information networks and education relating to the importance of maintaining genetic diversity and farrmer-level plant breeding. 19. Projects such as these are important to complement and provide a counter-balance to efforts to introduce and develop a limited number of high-yielding, modem varieties which are likely to require high levels of external inputs (fertilizers, irrigation, pest management) to be profitable, and therefore will not be appropriate for may small farmers. MOA responsible for the implementation of the SSMS, and the breeding programs of the IAR and AUA under this IDA-Financed project would coordinate with the PGRC/E and the On-farm Conservation project to benefit form the expertise and groundwork already established and to ensure that their efforts are complementary and mutually reinforcing. Accordingly, SSDP is providing funds to strengthen the institutional capacity of PGRC/E. Negative List of Pesticides 20. doc.abstracts: The Seed Systems Development Project will contribute to the national goal of increased agricultural production and productivity by laying the foundation for the development of a broad-based and competitive seed industry which draws its strength both from the formal and the informal seed system. The project supports Seed Policy Reform, through each of its two components. The components are : (a) Seed Enterprise Development; and (b) Capacity Building. The first component supports (i) the development of the informal seed sector; (ii) encourages private sector entry into the formal business; and supports (iii) the restructuring of the Ethiopian Seed Enterprise from a centrally managed parastatal to a decentralized and commercially oriented enterprise. The second component involves: (i) institutional strengthening; and (ii) human resource development, both in the formal and the informal sector.
